There lived some years ago in the town Of, In
Connecticut, man who was much addicted to the
practice of converting his neighbors property to his
own use benefit without If or and The clergyman
Of The town suspecting him of making too free with
his hay. had one night concealed himself in his barn
with his dark lantern. The thief soon appeared,
and tying up large bundle, had just left the pres
misses, when the Rev owner, instead Of bawling ou,s
/" you scoundrel you what do you mean by stealing
nv hay!" dsengaged the candle from the lantern
and dexerousy applied il TO the combusiible load.
The bundle was soon in bright blaze and the un-
lucky fellow, suspecting that he was pursued by
some person with light, laid his feet TO the ground
with uncommon agility. But It was in vain to es-
cape the pursuing fire. The blaze increasing IN
brightness he ran, seemed TO his terrified imagi.
naon to come nearer till yenturing to look round


to discover the extent OF his danger he perceived to
his asonishment that the stolen hay was on fire.
conscious guilt assisted his natural creduliiy, he set
tied down upon the conclusion, that the fire was
sent from heaven to admonish him OF his ransgres.
sions. Full OF this alar ming notion he gave himself
40 rest until he had gone to the pnrson and made
confession OF his crime and related the supposed
extraordinary and terrible warning from heaven.--


The Rev. gentleman humoured his credulity, IN,
der the idea that it might reform his lfe-He was


not mistaken for the blazing hay bad made SO
deep an impression on the poor fellows mind that
from thenceforth he forsook his evil courses be.


came valuable member of society, and was united


to the fiock OF the iudicious clergyman, who hao


sisted so materially in his reformation. He finally


died an honest man, in the firm belief of the inter-


position oil Poyider6e in setting fire to the stolen
] hay The parson kept the secret till the poor man


wa. laid in the DUST but then even the clerical


tongue could no longer resist the desire of commu


nicating SO curious an incident.
GOOD EFFECT OF CREDULITY.
A TRUE STORY.

coronet OF GEMS and gold

knew thee wed to wealth and state
Twas with foolish Joy:

But this-my once as sister-this
dream'd not to behold;
Thy candour into faschood turn'd
And thy once warm heart cold.
Ii jars the thoughts of former days,
To see thee as thou art
Farewell and can it be eief

Twas silence all the rising moon
With clouds had veild her light
The clock struck twelve, when 10. saw
A very chilling sight.
Pale as SNOWFALL was its faces
Like icicles its hair;
For mantle, it appeared 10 me
A sheet oil ice 10 wear.
Tho seldom given TO alarm
Indeed I'll not dissemble,
My teeth sll chatter'd in my head,
And every joint did tremble.
AT last cried, Pray who are you,
And whittier do you go?'
Methought the phantom thus replied
my name is Sally Snov:''
MY la,her's name is Northern Wind,
MY mothers name was Water;
Old Parson Winter married them,
And Pm their hopeful daughter.

mo 81 An ACT making appropriations for the payment
Of the Revolutionary and other Pensioners Of the Uni
ted States.


Be it enacted BY the Senate and House Of Repre-
sentatires Of the United States IF america in Con
gress assembled, That the following sums be and
they hereby, respectively appropriated towards
the military service Of the year one thousand eight
hundred and twentyseven, and for the objects fol.
lowing, that is to say:


For the pensions Of the Revolutionary pensioners
of the United States, one million two hundred and
sixty thousand one hundred and eighty five dollars


For the invalid and half pay pensioners, three
hundred and one thousand and fifty FIVE dollars;


For pensions to the widows and orphans, twelve
thousand dollars.


SEC Q. find be it further enacted, That the
said sums, respectively shall be paid out of any
money in the Treasury, not otherwise appropriated


Approved: January 90. 1927.

mo AN ACT to allow the citizens Of the Territory


of Michigan elect The members OF their Legislative


Council and for other purposes.


BE 1t enacted by the Senate and Uopse Of Repre-
spntatiues Of The U4ited States Of 4mprica in Con
grpSs assembled, That at the next, and at each
eeedng election of members OF the Legislative
Council oil he Territory Of Michigan, the qualified
electors Of the said Territory may. instead Of choos
ing twenty six, as heretofore directed elect thirteen
fl persons as their Representatives, in The manner
and with the qualifications now, or hereafter to be
prescribed, by law which said Representatives, SO
elected shall be, and constitute the said Legislative
Council. And for the purpose OF securing an equal
re representation, the Governor and Legislative Coun.
Gil OF said Territory hereby authorized and re.
ouired 10 apportion the Representatives, SO to be
elected as aforesaid among the several counties or
Districts in the said Territory, in proportion, near
as may be, to the whole number OF inhabitants in
each county or district, exclusive Of Indians no,
taxed.


Sec. O. .4nd be it further enacted, That the said
Cove rnor and Legislative Council be, and they are
hereby, authorized te provide by law for holding.
annually one or more Courts, by one more Of
the Judges Of the Supreme Court oil said Territory,
in each Of the counties in that part Of The Territory
Eastward oil the Lake Michigan; and also for the
appointment Of Clerk in each county, to act as
Clerk to the said Court therein and further to pre-
scribe the jurisdiction o said Courts and the powers
ard dptes OF the Judge Judges holding the same.


Sec 8. find be it further enacted, That the
Judges of the Supreme Court Of the Territory OF
Michigan have, and may exercise, the right of ap.
pointing the Clerk Of the said Court, and Of remoy-
ing HIM at pleasure.


Sec D. ind be it further enacted That no mem.
Der of the Legislative Council shall be eligible to
any Office created, or the ices of which regu


lated by law or laws passed whilst he was mem
ber during the period for which he was elected, and
Tor one year tht reafier.


Sec. S. find be ii further enacted That all laws
and parts Of laws, in so far the shall be in
consistent with the provisions Of this Act, hereby
repealed; and further tha, Congress have the right
at any time, to alter or repeal this Act


Approved 29th Jan. 1897.

full articles.headline: GOOD EFFECT OF CREDULITY.
full articles.article:
There lived some years ago in the town Of, In
Connecticut, man who was much addicted to the
practice of converting his neighbors property to his
own use benefit without If or and The clergyman
Of The town suspecting him of making too free with
his hay. had one night concealed himself in his barn
with his dark lantern. The thief soon appeared,
and tying up large bundle, had just left the pres
misses, when the Rev owner, instead Of bawling ou,s
/" you scoundrel you what do you mean by stealing
nv hay!" dsengaged the candle from the lantern
and dexerousy applied il TO the combusiible load.
The bundle was soon in bright blaze and the un-
lucky fellow, suspecting that he was pursued by
some person with light, laid his feet TO the ground
with uncommon agility. But It was in vain to es-
cape the pursuing fire. The blaze increasing IN
brightness he ran, seemed TO his terrified imagi.
naon to come nearer till yenturing to look round


to discover the extent OF his danger he perceived to
his asonishment that the stolen hay was on fire.
conscious guilt assisted his natural creduliiy, he set
tied down upon the conclusion, that the fire was
sent from heaven to admonish him OF his ransgres.
sions. Full OF this alar ming notion he gave himself
40 rest until he had gone to the pnrson and made
confession OF his crime and related the supposed
extraordinary and terrible warning from heaven.--


The Rev. gentleman humoured his credulity, IN,
der the idea that it might reform his lfe-He was


not mistaken for the blazing hay bad made SO
deep an impression on the poor fellows mind that
from thenceforth he forsook his evil courses be.


came valuable member of society, and was united


to the fiock OF the iudicious clergyman, who hao


sisted so materially in his reformation. He finally


died an honest man, in the firm belief of the inter-


position oil Poyider6e in setting fire to the stolen
] hay The parson kept the secret till the poor man


wa. laid in the DUST but then even the clerical


tongue could no longer resist the desire of commu


nicating SO curious an incident.

full articles.headline: TuU Fast.
full articles.article:
And Yeas havt pas. r!aoe isst gazed
Upon thy feufiIess LtoS-
Has, passed ,tho,n q sign Of change
Thou at lns, az .ovely how.
Yet somewhat there Of change has come,
Though what srarce may sa, s.
Thou look 'st a. hongh our parting Tour
Had been bui yesterday.
Thy lip smiles = hu, not with the smile
II wore in dai gone by;
IT'S studied as sunny mask,
TO hide the rising sigh.
coronet OF GEMS and gold
Is shining through thy hair;
Il is not worth the sweet wild flowers
That thou vert wont 10 wear.
Yet le. that pass and let Us talk
Over the days Of old -
O no. could moi speak OF them
To listener 50 cold
That smile, il freezes up ,hr flow
OF many kindly thought
That courtly careirssness And thus
With thee the world has wrought
Is this the sweet and simple girl
Whose iDmost soo would gush
A, her least word whose laugh and tear,
Were genuine as her blushr
knew thee wed to wealth and state
Twas with foolish Joy:
/ might have felt that all in life
Had its own deep alloy:
But this-my once as sister-this
dream'd not to behold;
Thy candour into faschood turn'd
And thy once warm heart cold.
Ii jars the thoughts of former days,
To see thee as thou art
Farewell and can it be eief
From one so loved to part


London Lit. Gaz.

full articles.headline: THE APPARITION.
full articles.article:
Twas silence all the rising moon
With clouds had veild her light
The clock struck twelve, when 10. saw
A very chilling sight.
Pale as SNOWFALL was its faces
Like icicles its hair;
For mantle, it appeared 10 me
A sheet oil ice 10 wear.
Tho seldom given TO alarm
Indeed I'll not dissemble,
My teeth sll chatter'd in my head,
And every joint did tremble.
AT last cried, Pray who are you,
And whittier do you go?'
Methought the phantom thus replied
my name is Sally Snov:''
MY la,her's name is Northern Wind,
MY mothers name was Water;
Old Parson Winter married them,
And Pm their hopeful daughter.
have lover, Jacky Frost,


MY dad tive match condemns:
I've ran from home to night, 10 meet
My lover on the Thames"
stopp'd Miss Snow in her discourset
This answer Just TO cast in
81 hope if Jack and you unite.
Your union won't be lasting:

which have compelled them to stop payment

"Every one has his day."-Whiis the Crane
and other Canals are fast-locked in ice and are
less, the six Rail Roads which dvrrbe from tbi+
CITY, are in tul activity affording numerous arrivals
daily With the rich products of places, some OF them
more than 400 miles distant.--The aggregate OF
wealth they furnish and carry back, woul6 not suf
fer in comparison with the celebrated Albany lists;
and we have this advantage, that our roads have
been furnished without cost, are in some cases toll
free and the rest levy very small tolls.

mo 81 An ACT making appropriations for the payment
Of the Revolutionary and other Pensioners Of the Uni
ted States.


Be it enacted BY the Senate and House Of Repre-
sentatires Of the United States IF america in Con
gress assembled, That the following sums be and
they hereby, respectively appropriated towards
the military service Of the year one thousand eight
hundred and twentyseven, and for the objects fol.
lowing, that is to say:


For the pensions Of the Revolutionary pensioners
of the United States, one million two hundred and
sixty thousand one hundred and eighty five dollars


For the invalid and half pay pensioners, three
hundred and one thousand and fifty FIVE dollars;


For pensions to the widows and orphans, twelve
thousand dollars.


SEC Q. find be it further enacted, That the
said sums, respectively shall be paid out of any
money in the Treasury, not otherwise appropriated


Approved: January 90. 1927.

mo AN ACT to allow the citizens Of the Territory


of Michigan elect The members OF their Legislative


Council and for other purposes.


BE 1t enacted by the Senate and Uopse Of Repre-
spntatiues Of The U4ited States Of 4mprica in Con
grpSs assembled, That at the next, and at each
eeedng election of members OF the Legislative
Council oil he Territory Of Michigan, the qualified
electors Of the said Territory may. instead Of choos
ing twenty six, as heretofore directed elect thirteen
fl persons as their Representatives, in The manner
and with the qualifications now, or hereafter to be
prescribed, by law which said Representatives, SO
elected shall be, and constitute the said Legislative
Council. And for the purpose OF securing an equal
re representation, the Governor and Legislative Coun.
Gil OF said Territory hereby authorized and re.
ouired 10 apportion the Representatives, SO to be
elected as aforesaid among the several counties or
Districts in the said Territory, in proportion, near
as may be, to the whole number OF inhabitants in
each county or district, exclusive Of Indians no,
taxed.


Sec. O. .4nd be it further enacted, That the said
Cove rnor and Legislative Council be, and they are
hereby, authorized te provide by law for holding.
annually one or more Courts, by one more Of
the Judges Of the Supreme Court oil said Territory,
in each Of the counties in that part Of The Territory
Eastward oil the Lake Michigan; and also for the
appointment Of Clerk in each county, to act as
Clerk to the said Court therein and further to pre-
scribe the jurisdiction o said Courts and the powers
ard dptes OF the Judge Judges holding the same.


Sec 8. find be it further enacted, That the
Judges of the Supreme Court Of the Territory OF
Michigan have, and may exercise, the right of ap.
pointing the Clerk Of the said Court, and Of remoy-
ing HIM at pleasure.


Sec D. ind be it further enacted That no mem.
Der of the Legislative Council shall be eligible to
any Office created, or the ices of which regu


lated by law or laws passed whilst he was mem
ber during the period for which he was elected, and
Tor one year tht reafier.


Sec. S. find be ii further enacted That all laws
and parts Of laws, in so far the shall be in
consistent with the provisions Of this Act, hereby
repealed; and further tha, Congress have the right
at any time, to alter or repeal this Act


Approved 29th Jan. 1897.
